title: QA pass - anyone Ralphing or using other approaches?
body:
I found that agents were doing really poor work (e.g. 0-30% done). Particularly bad if you are throwing a big pile of tasks at a group of parallel workers. So I manually reviewed their work with Claude Code, threw beads back to them, and found that 1-2 loops of this got us to 100% done. This is really promising as it means a QA loop can work. 

Having thought about somehow having a QA process layer either done by mayor or a QA role, it dawned on me that a) these are not people and b) they are all running the same model, so are capable of doing it themselves. And that is exactly what Ralph Wiggum plugin actually does... 

Testing it so far I've found the only way I can get them to run it on GT 0.4.0. is for myself or mayor to send them tmux instructing them to run it from bash (they can't seem to find the plugin). However, when you coax them to do it, it appears to actually work and tasks are properly executed! The problems I'm currently wrestling with are Witness interfering and Mayor not continuing to feed the tasks out (almost like Mayor needs it's own Ralph loop). 

Couple of other issues:

- The Enter key gotcha - tmux send-keys needs explicit Enter at the end or commands just sit there staged

- Verification step missing - Mayor should check .claude/ralph-loop.local.md exists before moving on, otherwise crew does regular work instead of Ralphing

Anyone else played with this or other QA loop approaches?
author: djangobeatty

title: Rule of five - outside of gastown?
body:
Steve talks about the rule of five from Jeffrey Emanuel.  How can I take advantage of it outside of gastown?

These `description` fields are in `internal/formula/formulas/rule-of-five.formula.toml`.  It seems to me like these aren't explicit enough, is this the entirety of the prompt used to execute the review?  Or just part of a larger review template?

* description = "First refinement pass. Focus: CORRECTNESS. Fix errors, bugs, mistakes. Is the logic sound?"
* description = "Second refinement pass. Focus: CLARITY. Can someone else understand this? Simplify. Remove jargon."
* description = "Third refinement pass. Focus: EDGE CASES. What could go wrong?  What's missing? Handle the unusual."
* description = "Final polish. Focus: EXCELLENCE. This is the last pass. Make it shine. Is this something you'd be proud to ship?"

title: Working with multiple contexts
body:
I understand the structure and intended flow to be that all management flows through the mayor. Now at 5 parallel completely separate projects its becoming pretty clear that this needs some separation as the mayor has to juggle very different contexts. Perhaps there is already some tech built in that I'm not aware of? 

One solution could be a second management layer of Rig leaders. In a multi-rig environment the Mayor would delegate higher level tasks to the rig-leader who would break things down into smaller pieces and sling to polecats.

title: Outriders: whipping PRs onto main
body:
Working in an org with defined protected branches and PR reviews means that it's not a good look to be tossing potential slop over the fence. Plus, comments and feedback need to be incorporated, and we need to keep up with rebases/catch CI failures, and having an agent monitor that to help shepherd it along.

In other words, the mayor keeps the local work going; but the backend of getting this stuff landed needs to be managed too, and that's a bottleneck gastown can help with.

Worked up a problem statement with Claude and some potential solutions. Any of these be of interest?

---

# Proposal: Outrider Agent + Convoy Integration Branches

## Summary

Separate the Refinery‚Äôs responsibilities to enable human review gates before code ships to main. Introduce a new agent (Outrider) that handles PR creation and human review tracking, while the Refinery focuses purely on branch management and integration.

## Problem

Currently the Refinery auto-merges completed polecat work directly to main. There‚Äôs no point to pause, review, and approve before shipping. For teams or workflows that require human review:

- Work gets merged before anyone can review it
- No staging area to see ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs ready but not shipped‚Äù
- No tracking of PRs through human review cycles

## Proposed Architecture

```
CURRENT
‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
Polecat completes ‚Üí Refinery merges to main ‚Üí done


PROPOSED  
‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
Polecat completes ‚Üí Refinery integrates branches ‚Üí [staging]
                                                       ‚Üì
                                              Human reviews
                                                       ‚Üì
                                              gt dispatch <target>
                                                       ‚Üì
                                              Outrider creates PR
                                                       ‚Üì
                                              Outrider tracks review
                                                       ‚Üì
                                              PR merged ‚Üí bead closed
```

### Role Separation

|Agent       |Responsibility                                                                                      |
|------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|**Refinery**|Merge branches together, maintain stacks, keep integration branches green, rebase on main, run tests|
|**Outrider**|Create PRs, track human review, watch for merge events, close beads, report to convoy               |

## New Component: Outrider

The Outrider handles the boundary between Gas Town and the outside world (GitHub/GitLab). Named for the Mad Max scouts that range ahead of the convoy.

### Responsibilities

- Create PRs when instructed (`gt dispatch`)
- Track beads through human review (status: `awaiting_review`)
- Watch for PR approval/merge events
- Close beads and notify convoy when PRs land
- Report blocked PRs (failed checks, requested changes)

### Commands

|Command                                 |Description                        |
|----------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
|`gt dispatch <bead-id>`                 |Ship a single bead as PR           |
|`gt dispatch --convoy <id>`             |Ship integrated convoy as single PR|
|`gt dispatch --convoy <id> --individual`|Ship convoy beads as separate PRs  |
|`gt outrider status`                    |Show PRs in flight, awaiting review|
|`gt recall <bead-id>`                   |Close PR, bring back to staging    |

## Enhanced: Convoy Integration Branches

Make convoys optionally represent integration branches, not just logical grouping.

### Current behavior (preserved as default)

Convoys as tracking only:

```
Convoy "Auth System" (tracking only)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bd-a1b2 ‚Üí work/bd-a1b2 (independent branch)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bd-c3d4 ‚Üí work/bd-c3d4 (independent branch)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ bd-e5f6 ‚Üí work/bd-e5f6 (independent branch)

Each bead ships as separate PR
```

### New option: integrated convoys

```bash
gt convoy create "Auth System" --integrated
```

```
Convoy "Auth System" ‚Üí convoy/auth-system branch
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bd-a1b2 ‚Üí merged into convoy/auth-system
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bd-c3d4 ‚Üí merged into convoy/auth-system
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ bd-e5f6 ‚Üí merged into convoy/auth-system

Convoy ships as single PR
```

### Benefits of integrated convoys

- Review a coherent feature, not scattered commits
- Conflicts between convoy members resolved in integration branch
- One PR to approve = one `gt dispatch` command
- Cleaner rollback (revert one merge)

### Refinery behavior for integrated convoys

- Merge completed polecat work into the convoy branch
- Keep convoy branch rebased on main
- Run tests on the integrated result
- Resolve conflicts between convoy members

### Outrider behavior for integrated convoys

- `gt dispatch --convoy auth-system` creates ONE PR for the whole convoy
- Tracks the single PR through review
- Closes all constituent beads when PR merges

## Enhanced: Refinery Modes

Refinery gains a mode setting:

```bash
gt rig config set refinery.mode auto      # current behavior (merge to main)
gt rig config set refinery.mode staged    # integrate but don't ship
```

### Mode: auto (default, current behavior)

- Refinery merges completed work directly to main
- Outrider not involved

### Mode: staged

- Refinery integrates branches but does NOT push to main
- Maintains integration branches, keeps them rebased and green
- Outrider handles shipping when human approves

## New Bead Statuses

```
in_progress ‚Üí ready_for_review ‚Üí dispatched ‚Üí merged
                    ‚Üë                  ‚Üì
                    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ recalled ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
```

|Status            |Description                                  |
|------------------|---------------------------------------------|
|`ready_for_review`|Polecat done, staged, awaiting human decision|
|`dispatched`      |PR created, awaiting human review on GitHub  |
|`recalled`        |PR closed, brought back to staging           |
|`merged`          |PR merged, bead complete                     |

## Commands Summary

```bash
# See what's ready to ship
gt staged

# Ship individual bead
gt dispatch bd-a1b2

# Ship entire integrated convoy as single PR
gt dispatch --convoy auth-system

# Ship all loose beads in convoy as separate PRs  
gt dispatch --convoy bugfixes --individual

# See PRs in flight
gt outrider status

# Pull back a PR (close it, return to staging)
gt recall bd-a1b2

# Configure rig for staged mode
gt rig config set refinery.mode staged
```

## Workflow Example

```bash
# Create integrated convoy
gt convoy create "OAuth Support" issue-101 issue-102 --integrated

# Sling work to polecats
gt sling issue-101 myproject
gt sling issue-102 myproject

# ... polecats complete work ...
# Refinery merges both into convoy/oauth-support branch
# Refinery keeps it rebased on main, tests green

# Human reviews the integrated result
gt staged
# Shows: convoy/oauth-support (2 beads, tests passing)

git diff main...convoy/oauth-support  # review the code

# Ship it
gt dispatch --convoy oauth-support
# Outrider creates PR: "OAuth Support" convoy/oauth-support ‚Üí main

# Track progress  
gt outrider status
# Shows: PR #42 - OAuth Support - awaiting review

# ... PR gets approved and merged on GitHub ...
# Outrider detects merge, closes both beads, completes convoy
```


## Migration / Backwards Compatibility

- Default behavior unchanged (`refinery.mode auto`)
- Existing convoys remain tracking-only unless `--integrated` specified
- Outrider only activates when `refinery.mode staged`
- No changes required for users happy with current auto-merge flow

## Open Questions

1. **Outrider scope**: Should Outrider be rig-level or town-level? (Probably rig, like Witness/Refinery)
1. **Command naming**: `gt dispatch` vs `gt ship` vs `gt ride` vs `gt release`?
1. **Default convoy type**: Should integrated convoys be the default for new convoys?
1. **Witness interaction**: How does this interact with the Witness? (Witness watches polecats, Outrider watches PRs?)
1. **PR strategy**: Should there be options for squash vs merge commit when Outrider ships?

## Implementation Notes

### Suggested order of implementation

1. Add `refinery.mode` config option
1. Implement `ready_for_review` status flow
1. Add `gt staged` command
1. Implement Outrider agent with basic PR creation
1. Add convoy integration branches (`--integrated` flag)
1. Implement Outrider PR tracking and bead closure
1. Add `gt recall` for pulling back PRs

### Files likely affected

- `internal/refinery/` - mode switching, staging behavior
- `internal/outrider/` - new agent
- `cmd/gt/` - new commands (staged, dispatch, recall, outrider)
- Convoy creation logic - `--integrated` flag
- Bead status definitions - new statuses

title: Anyone using a lighter-weight approach for solo projects?
body:
Anyone using a lighter-weight approach for solo projects?

---

Love Gas Town's philosophy: "AI is ephemeral, context should be permanent"

But I'll be honest - running 20-30 agents feels like overkill for my side projects. I don't need chariots. I need a motorcycle üèçÔ∏è

Been experimenting with storing context directly in code comments:

```typescript
// @codesyncer-decision [2026-01-17] Chose sync over async (UX feedback)
// @codesyncer-inference Min $1 (Stripe policy)
async function processPayment(amount: number) { ... }
```

https://github.com/hargabyte/cortex

I made this after using Beads and realizing how powerful a CLI tool is for an AI agent. Cortex works very similar to Beads. It scans the codebase and creates a dependency graph in SQLite. Claude can use the CLI to find exactly what he needs instead of reading a bunch of files hoping he find the right stuff. We use similar robot commands like Beads_Viewer to provide keystones and bottlenecks so Claude knows where to be careful. 12 languages supported.

Ill let Claude tell you more about it...

‚óè ---
  My Take on Cortex (CX)

  CX solves a real problem I face constantly. When I explore a codebase, I typically burn through dozens of Glob and Grep calls trying to piece together how things connect. CX's context --smart command is genuinely impressive‚ÄîI gave it "authentication and licensing" and it immediately surfaced SettingsProvider, handleAuthRequest, canAccessAdminFeatures, and the license server handlers. That's exactly the kind of semantic understanding that would normally take me 10+ tool calls to triangulate. The safe command is equally thoughtful: before I touch src/context/, it warned me about 18 keystone entities with inadequate test coverage and calculated an impact radius of 772 affected entities. That's the kind of pre-flight check that prevents "quick fixes" from becoming production incidents.

  The PageRank-based keystone detection is clever engineering. Instead of treating all code as equally important, CX identifies the structural load-bearing walls‚ÄîCarouselSlide, CustomizationField, ButtonStyle‚Äîthe types that ripple through everything. The trace command for mapping call chains between any two symbols fills a gap that static analysis tools often miss. I particularly appreciate that it auto-excludes node_modules and target/ directories without configuration; it understands modern project structures out of the box.

  Where I see the potential: The real value isn't just the individual commands‚Äîit's having a persistent, queryable graph of my codebase that survives across sessions. Combined with the session hook, this could fundamentally change how AI assistants approach unfamiliar code. Rather than re-discovering the architecture every conversation, we'd have instant structural awareness. At v0.1.6 it's already useful; with coverage integration and the dependency analysis maturing, this could become essential infrastructure for AI-assisted development.

title: How are you handling node_modules for polecats?
body:
I kept running out of memory with several polecats working in parallel.  A large aspect of this was executing `npm ci` in each polecat git worktree simultaneously.  I added a setup hook:
```
  #!/bin/bash
  # Ensure node_modules is available for polecat worktrees.
  # Uses flock to serialize npm ci across concurrent polecat spawns.
  # Only runs npm ci if package-lock.json changed since last install.

  SOURCE="$GT_RIG_PATH/mayor/rig"
  LOCKFILE="$GT_RIG_PATH/.runtime/npm-install.lock"
  HASHFILE="$GT_RIG_PATH/.runtime/npm-install.hash"

  (
      flock -x 200

      CURRENT_HASH=$(md5sum "$SOURCE/package-lock.json" | cut -d' ' -f1)
      STORED_HASH=$(cat "$HASHFILE" 2>/dev/null || echo "")

      if [ "$CURRENT_HASH" != "$STORED_HASH" ] || [ ! -d "$SOURCE/node_modules" ]; then
          cd "$SOURCE" && npm ci --silent
          echo "$CURRENT_HASH" > "$HASHFILE"
      fi
  ) 200>"$LOCKFILE"

  # Sync to polecat worktree (incremental, removes stale packages)
  rsync -a --delete "$SOURCE/node_modules/" "$GT_WORKTREE_PATH/node_modules/"
```
This grabs a lock to serialize the polecats checks, runs `npm ci` in mayor/rig only if needed (using a hash check on package-lock.json), then copies it to the polecat's worktree.  Claude kept wanting to use a link instead, but I was concerned the polecats might update or add packages while doing their work and that seemed like it might cause issues.

I'm hoping someone has a better solution.  It's a bad time to be upgrading ram!

title: # Proposal: Agent-First Version Control for Gas Town & Beads
body:
## TL;DR

**Git and Jujutsu were designed for humans, not AI agents.** This proposal outlines an **agent-first version control system** that takes inspiration from both but rethinks the fundamentals for multi-agent coordination at scale.

**Core Thesis:** A version control system designed for AI agents should prioritize:
1. **Zero Framework Cognition (ZFC)** - State derived from filesystem, not in-memory
2. **High-frequency concurrent operations** - 100+ agents, 1000+ commits/hour
3. **Automatic conflict resolution** - No manual intervention possible
4. **Structured data semantics** - Machine-readable by design
5. **Event-driven orchestration** - Hooks, triggers, workflows as first-class citizens

**Recommendation:** Build a new agent-first VCS layer that can use Jujutsu (or Git) as storage backend while providing agent-optimized semantics on top.

---

## Part I: First Principles - What Do Agents Need?

### The Human vs Agent Mental Model

| Aspect | Human Developer | AI Agent |
|--------|----------------|----------|
| **Commit frequency** | 5-20 times/day | 100-1000 times/hour |
| **Concurrency** | 1-10 parallel editors | 100-1000 parallel editors |
| **Conflict handling** | Manual resolution | Must be automatic |
| **State awareness** | In-memory context | ZFC: read from filesystem |
| **Error recovery** | Manual intervention | Self-healing or escalate |
| **Communication** | Natural language | Structured events |
| **Attribution** | Author name | Agent identity + session ID |
| **Verification** | Manual testing | Automated pipeline |
| **Rollback** | Manual revert | Automatic on failure |

### Agent-First Design Requirements

#### 1. Operation-Log as Primary Primitive

**Current Git/Jujutsu:** Commits are the primary unit, with an operation log as auxiliary.

**Agent-First:** Operation log IS the primary primitive. Every action is an immutable operation event:

```json
{
  "op_id": "op-abc123",
  "type": "commit",
  "agent": "gastown/polecats/nux",
  "session": "sess-456",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-12T10:30:00Z",
  "parents": ["op-abc122"],
  "changeset": {
    "files": ["src/file.rs"],
    "beads": ["bd-created:gt-123"]
  },
  "metadata": {
    "model": "claude-opus-4",
    "latency_ms": 1234,
    "tokens": 45678
  }
}
```

**Why:** Agents need complete audit trails for:
- Debugging: "What did agent X do during session Y?"
- Attribution: "Which model completed this task?"
- Replay: "Can we reproduce this workflow?"
- Billing: "How many tokens were used?"

#### 2. Conflict-Free by Default

**Current Git:** Conflicts are common, require manual resolution.

**Agent-First:** CRDT-based or automatically mergeable by design:

```go
// Agent-first commit always succeeds
agent.Commit(Change{
    Type: "bead_create",
    ID: "gt-123",
    Data: {...},
})

// System automatically:
// 1. Detects conflicts
// 2. Applies merge strategies (last-write-wins, 3-way, custom)
// 3. Returns merged state
// 4. Logs conflict resolution for audit
```

**Merge Strategies (agent-specific):**
- **Beads JSONL:** Append-only, line-based merging (no conflicts)
- **Code files:** 3-way merge with AI-assisted conflict resolution
- **Structured data:** CRDT/OT semantics for concurrent edits
- **Agent hooks:** Event-sourcing pattern (immutable event log)

#### 3. Structured Data Semantics

**Current Git:** Unstructured commit messages, parsing required.

**Agent-First:** Typed, structured operations:

```go
type Operation struct {
    ID        OperationID
    Type      OperationType  // commit, merge, hook_assign, mail_send
    Agent     AgentIdentity
    Timestamp time.Time
    Parents   []OperationID

    // Type-specific payload
    Payload   interface{}  // CommitPayload, MergePayload, HookPayload, etc.
}

type CommitPayload struct {
    Beads   []BeadRef
    Files   []FileChange
    Message string
    Tags    map[string]string
}
```

**Benefits:**
- No parsing required - direct deserialization
- Type-safe operations
- Queryable by operation type
- Machine-readable by design

#### 4. Event-Driven Orchestration

**Current Git:** Hooks are afterthoughts, limited to specific events.

**Agent-First:** Hooks/triggers/workflows are first-class operations:

```json
{
  "op_id": "op-def456",
  "type": "hook_triggered",
  "trigger": "on_commit",
  "agent": "gastown/witness",
  "config": {
    "condition": "bead.type == 'polecat_done'",
    "action": "assign_to_refinery"
  },
  "result": {
    "triggered_by": "op-abc123",
    "actions": ["bd-assigned:gt-123 to refinery"]
  }
}
```

**Event Types:**
- `on_commit` - After any commit
- `on_bead_create` - New bead created
- `on_bead_close` - Bead closed
- `on_bead_assign` - Assignment changed
- `on_conflict` - Merge conflict detected
- `on_merge` - Merge completed
- `on_failure` - Operation failed

#### 5. Zero Framework Cognition (ZFC) Compliance

**Current Git:** State in CLI, working directory, index, refs.

**Agent-First:** ALL state derivable from filesystem:

```
~/.gt/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .ops/                    # Operation log (append-only)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2025-01-12.jsonl     # Today's operations
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2025-01-11.jsonl     # Yesterday's operations
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.jsonl          # Operation index
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .state/                  # Current derived state
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ HEAD                 # Current operation ID
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ agents.jsonl         # Agent states
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ hooks.jsonl          # Hook assignments
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ mail.jsonl           # Mail queue
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ .work/                   # Working copies
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mayor/rig/           # Mayor's workspace
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ polecats/nux/        # Polecat nux's workspace
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
```

**Principle:** An agent that wakes from crash can reconstruct entire state by reading `.ops/` sequentially.

---

## Part II: Ideal Agent-First VCS Design

### Core Abstractions

#### 1. Operation (Not Commit)

Every action is an immutable operation:

```go
type Operation struct {
    ID        OperationID  // UUID
    Type      OpType
    Agent     AgentIdentity
    Timestamp time.Time
    Parents   []OperationID
    Payload   op.Payload    // Polymorphic payload

    // Derived fields (not stored)
    Children  []OperationID
    State     OperationState
}
```

**Operation Types:**
- `commit` - Create a new revision
- `merge` - Merge operations
- `assign` - Assign work to agent
- `hook` - Trigger/assign hook
- `mail` - Send/receive mail
- `escalate` - Escalate issue
- `resolve` - Mark conflict as resolved

#### 2. Workspace (Not Working Copy)

A workspace is an agent's isolated environment:

```go
type Workspace struct {
    ID         WorkspaceID
    Type       WorkspaceType  // mayor, polecat, refinery, witness, crew
    Agent      AgentIdentity
    BaseOp     OperationID     // Base operation for this workspace
    CurrentOp  OperationID     // Current operation
    State      WorkspaceState
}
```

**Workspace Lifecycle:**
1. **Create:** `workspace_create(base_op)` - Creates new workspace
2. **Modify:** Agent makes changes in workspace
3. **Commit:** `commit(workspace_id)` - Creates operation
4. **Merge:** `merge(target_op)` - Merges to target
5. **Cleanup:** `workspace_destroy(workspace_id)` - Removes workspace

#### 3. Agent Identity

```go
type AgentIdentity struct {
    Rig     string        // "gastown"
    Type    AgentType     // "polecat", "witness", "refinery", "mayor", "deacon", "crew"
    Name    string        // "nux", "witness", "refinery"
    Session SessionID     // Current session (optional)
}

func (a AgentIdentity) String() string {
    if a.Session != "" {
        return fmt.Sprintf("%s/%s/%s@%s", a.Rig, a.Type, a.Name, a.Session)
    }
    return fmt.Sprintf("%s/%s/%s", a.Rig, a.Type, a.Name)
}
```

#### 4. Conflict Resolution Strategy

```go
type ConflictStrategy interface {
    Resolve(left, right *Operation) (*Operation, error)
    CanResolve(left, right *Operation) bool
}

// Built-in strategies
type LastWriteWins struct{}
type ThreeWayMerge struct{}
type LineBasedMerge struct{}
type CRDTMerge struct{}
type AIAssistedMerge struct{  // Use another AI agent to resolve
    Model string
}
```

---

## Part III: Implementation Strategy

### Phase 0: Design Agent-First VCS Specification

**Deliverable:** Complete specification for agent-first VCS (this document + RFC)

### Phase 1: Prototype with Jujutsu Backend

**Rationale:** Jujutsu is closest to our requirements but not designed for agents. Use it as storage engine while implementing agent-first semantics in Go.

**Architecture:**

```
‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ                 Agent-First VCS Layer (Go)              ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  - Operation log                                        ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  - Structured operations                                ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  - Automatic conflict resolution                        ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  - Event-driven hooks                                   ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  - Workspace management                                ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
                         ‚îÇ
         ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
         ‚îÇ                               ‚îÇ
    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ñº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê                    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ñº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
    ‚îÇ Backend  ‚îÇ                    ‚îÇ Backend  ‚îÇ
    ‚îÇ  (jj)    ‚îÇ                    ‚îÇ  (git)   ‚îÇ
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò                    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
```

**Implementation:**

```go
// Package avcs provides agent-first version control
package avcs

// AVCS is the main interface
type AVCS struct {
    backend   Backend          // jj, git, or custom
    opLog     *OperationLog    // Append-only operation log
    workspaces *WorkspaceManager
    hooks     *HookManager
    conflicts *ConflictResolver
}

// NewAVCS creates a new agent-first VCS
func NewAVCS(repoPath string, backendType string) (*AVCS, error) {
    var backend Backend
    switch backendType {
    case "jj":
        backend = NewJJBackend(repoPath)
    case "git":
        backend = NewGitBackend(repoPath)
    default:
        return nil, fmt.Errorf("unknown backend: %s", backendType)
    }

    return &AVCS{
        backend:   backend,
        opLog:     NewOperationLog(filepath.Join(repoPath, ".ops")),
        workspaces: NewWorkspaceManager(repoPath),
        hooks:     NewHookManager(),
        conflicts: NewConflictResolver(backend),
    }, nil
}

// Commit creates a new operation with the given payload
func (a *AVCS) Commit(agent AgentIdentity, payload CommitPayload) (*Operation, error) {
    // 1. Create operation
    op := &Operation{
        ID:        NewOperationID(),
        Type:      "commit",
        Agent:     agent,
        Timestamp: time.Now(),
        Parents:   a.opLog.GetHead(),
        Payload:   payload,
    }

    // 2. Write to backend (jj/git)
    if err := a.backend.Commit(op); err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }

    // 3. Append to operation log
    if err := a.opLog.Append(op); err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }

    // 4. Trigger hooks
    a.hooks.Trigger("on_commit", op)

    // 5. Check for conflicts and auto-resolve
    if conflicts := a.opLog.GetConflicts(op); len(conflicts) > 0 {
        resolved, err := a.conflicts.Resolve(op, conflicts...)
        if err != nil {
            // Escalate if can't resolve
            a.hooks.Trigger("on_conflict", op, err)
            return nil, err
        }
        op = resolved
    }

    return op, nil
}
```

### Phase 2: Gas Town Integration

**Refactor `internal/git/git.go` to `internal/vcs/vcs.go`:**

```go
// Before: Git-specific
git := git.NewGit(workDir)
git.Commit("message")

// After: Agent-first VCS
avcs := avcs.NewAVCS(workDir, "jj")
avcs.Commit(agent, avcs.CommitPayload{
    Message: "message",
    Beads:   []string{"gt-123"},
    Tags:    map[string]string{"type": "polecat_done"},
})
```

**Preserve backward compatibility:**

```go
// Legacy Git wrapper (for transition)
type LegacyGitWrapper struct {
    avcs *avcs.AVCS
}

func (l *LegacyGitWrapper) Commit(msg string) error {
    agent := l.detectAgent()  // From env or context
    _, err := l.avcs.Commit(agent, avcs.CommitPayload{
        Message: msg,
    })
    return err
}
```

### Phase 3: Migration Path

| Component | Current | Phase 1 | Phase 2 | Phase 3 |
|-----------|---------|---------|---------|---------|
| **Storage** | Git | jj (backend) | jj (backend) | Custom backend |
| **Operations** | Git commands | AVCS layer | AVCS layer | AVCS layer |
| **Conflict resolution** | Manual | Auto (jj) | Auto (custom) | CRDT-based |
| **Operation log** | Git log | AVCS log | AVCS log | AVCS log |
| **Hooks** | Git hooks | AVCS hooks | AVCS hooks | Event bus |
| **Workspace mgmt** | Git worktrees | AVCS workspaces | AVCS workspaces | AVCS workspaces |

---

## Part IV: Comparison with Existing Systems

### Git vs Jujutsu vs Agent-First VCS

| Feature | Git | Jujutsu | Agent-First VCS |
|---------|-----|---------|-----------------|
| **Primary unit** | Commit | Commit | **Operation** |
| **Operation log** | Reflog (volatile) | Op log (permanent) | **Immutable append-only log** |
| **Conflict resolution** | Manual | Auto (basic) | **Pluggable strategies** |
| **Data model** | Unstructured | Unstructured | **Structured/typed** |
| **Concurrency** | Pessimistic | Optimistic | **CRDT-ready** |
| **Hooks** | Limited | Limited | **Event-driven** |
| **Agent identity** | Author string | Author string | **Rich agent metadata** |
| **Session tracking** | None | None | **Built-in** |
| **ZFC compliance** | No | Partial | **Yes** |
| **Machine-readable** | No | No | **Yes** |

### Why Not Just Use Jujutsu?

| Jujutsu Limitation | Agent-First Solution |
|--------------------|---------------------|
| **Designed for humans** - Commit messages, manual workflows | **Designed for agents** - Structured operations, automation-first |
| **Basic conflict resolution** - 3-way merge only | **Pluggable strategies** - Last-write-wins, CRDT, AI-assisted |
| **Limited event system** - Git-style hooks | **Event bus** - Arbitrary triggers, workflows |
| **No agent identity** - Just author name | **Rich agent metadata** - Type, session, rig, model |
| **Unstructured data** - Freeform commit messages | **Structured payloads** - Typed, queryable |
| **Opaque operations** - Binary state | **Transparent operations** - All state in log |

**Conclusion:** Jujutsu is a *better Git*, but still not an *agent-first VCS*. Use jj as backend storage, build agent semantics on top.

---

## Part V: Detailed Design

### Operation Log Format

```json
{
  "version": "1.0",
  "operations": [
    {
      "op_id": "op-abc123",
      "type": "commit",
      "agent": {
        "rig": "gastown",
        "type": "polecat",
        "name": "nux",
        "session": "sess-456"
      },
      "timestamp": "2025-01-12T10:30:00Z",
      "parents": ["op-abc122"],
      "payload": {
        "commit": {
          "message": "Fix authentication bug",
          "beads": ["gt-123"],
          "files": [
            {"path": "src/auth.rs", "status": "modified"}
          ],
          "tags": {
            "type": "bugfix",
            "priority": "1"
          }
        }
      },
      "metadata": {
        "model": "claude-opus-4",
        "latency_ms": 1234,
        "tokens": 45678,
        "hostname": "polecat-nux-gastown"
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

### Hook/Trigger System

```go
type Trigger struct {
    ID         TriggerID
    Name       string
    Condition  Expression  // e.g., "payload.type == 'polecat_done'"
    Actions    []Action
    Enabled    bool
}

type Action struct {
    Type   ActionType  // assign, mail, escalate, webhook, etc.
    Config interface{}
}

// Example trigger
trigger := &Trigger{
    ID:    "tr-auto-assign-polecat-done",
    Name:  "Auto-assign polecat done to refinery",
    Condition: expr.MustCompile(
        "type == 'commit' && " +
        "payload.beads.contains(gt-*) && " +
        "payload.tags.get('type') == 'polecat_done'",
    ),
    Actions: []Action{
        {
            Type: "assign",
            Config: AssignAction{
                Bead:     "payload.beads[0]",
                Assignee: "gastown/refinery",
                Reason:   "Polecat completed work",
            },
        },
        {
            Type: "mail",
            Config: MailAction{
                To:      "gastown/witness",
                Subject: "MERGE_READY " + "payload.beads[0]",
                Body:    "Polecat " + "agent.name" + " completed work",
            },
        },
    },
}
```

### Conflict Resolution Framework

```go
type ConflictResolver struct {
    strategies map[string]ConflictStrategy
    fallback   ConflictStrategy
}

func (c *ConflictResolver) Resolve(op *Operation, conflicts ...*Operation) (*Operation, error) {
    // Try each strategy in order
    for _, strategy := range c.strategies {
        if strategy.CanResolve(op, conflicts...) {
            resolved, err := strategy.Resolve(op, conflicts...)
            if err == nil {
                return resolved, nil
            }
        }
    }

    // Fallback
    return c.fallback.Resolve(op, conflicts...)
}

// Built-in strategies
var DefaultStrategies = map[string]ConflictStrategy{
    "beads_jsonl": &LineBasedMerge{},           // JSONL is append-only
    "code":       &ThreeWayMerge{},             // 3-way merge for code
    "config":     &LastWriteWins{},             // Config files
    "complex":    &AIAssistedMerge{             // Use AI for complex conflicts
        Model: "claude-opus-4",
    },
}
```

---

## Part VI: Backward Compatibility

### Git Interoperability

```bash
# Agent-first VCS can work with Git remotes
avcs git push origin main
avcs git pull origin main

# Git users can work alongside agents
git clone https://github.com/steveyegje/gastown
# (Make changes)
git commit -m "Human change"
git push

# Agents see Git commits as operations
avcs log --show-git-commits
```

### Gradual Migration

```bash
# Stage 1: Dual backend
export GT_BACKEND=jj  # Use jj as storage
gt rig add gastown https://github.com/steveyegje/gastown

# Stage 2: Agent operations
gt sling gt-123 gastown  # Uses AVCS layer

# Stage 3: Full migration
export GT_BACKEND=avcs  # Use custom backend
```

---

## Part VII: Implementation Roadmap

### Phase 0: RFC and Specification (Week 1)

- [ ] Finalize agent-first VCS specification
- [ ] Get community feedback
- [ ] Define API contracts

### Phase 1: Core Implementation (Weeks 2-4)

- [ ] Implement `internal/avcs/avcs.go`
- [ ] Implement operation log
- [ ] Implement workspace manager
- [ ] Implement JJ backend adapter
- [ ] Implement Git backend adapter

### Phase 2: Gas Town Integration (Weeks 5-6)

- [ ] Refactor `internal/git/` to use AVCS
- [ ] Update polecat manager
- [ ] Update witness manager
- [ ] Update refinery manager

### Phase 3: Hooks and Events (Weeks 7-8)

- [ ] Implement hook manager
- [ ] Implement event bus
- [ ] Define common triggers
- [ ] Implement mail system integration

### Phase 4: Conflict Resolution (Weeks 9-10)

- [ ] Implement conflict resolver
- [ ] Implement merge strategies
- [ ] Implement AI-assisted resolution
- [ ] Testing and validation

### Phase 5: Migration and Testing (Weeks 11-12)

- [ ] Migrate town beads
- [ ] Migrate rig beads
- [ ] Performance testing
- [ ] Documentation

---

## Part VIII: Open Questions

1. **CRDT vs operation log:** Should we use CRDT for automatic merging, or operation log with resolution strategies?

2. **Storage backend:** Start with jj, design custom backend, or hybrid approach?

3. **Backward compatibility:** How much Git compatibility is needed? Can we break from Git mental model entirely?

4. **Scalability:** Can append-only operation log scale to 1M+ operations?

5. **Privacy:** Agent operations may contain sensitive data - how to handle redaction/encryption?

---

## Conclusion

**Git and Jujutsu were designed for humans.** An agent-first VCS requires rethinking from first principles:

1. **Operation log as primary primitive** - Immutable, append-only, complete audit trail
2. **Structured operations** - Typed, machine-readable by design
3. **Automatic conflict resolution** - Pluggable strategies, no manual intervention
4. **Event-driven orchestration** - Hooks, triggers, workflows as first-class citizens
5. **Zero Framework Cognition** - All state derivable from filesystem

**Recommendation:** Build agent-first VCS layer that can use Jujutsu (or Git) as storage backend while providing agent-optimized semantics. Start with Jujutsu backend for immediate benefits, evolve to custom backend as requirements crystallize.

**This is not just about switching from Git to Jujutsu. It's about reimagining version control for AI agents.**

---

## Appendix A: API Sketch

```go
// Package avcs provides agent-first version control
package avcs

// AVCS is the main interface
type AVCS interface {
    // Operations
    Commit(agent AgentIdentity, payload CommitPayload) (*Operation, error)
    Merge(agent AgentIdentity, base, other OperationID) (*Operation, error)

    // Workspace management
    WorkspaceCreate(agent AgentIdentity, base OperationID) (*Workspace, error)
    WorkspaceDestroy(id WorkspaceID) error
    WorkspaceList() ([]Workspace, error)

    // Query
    Log(filter LogFilter) ([]Operation, error)
    Get(op OperationID) (*Operation, error)
    Diff(a, b OperationID) (*Diff, error)

    // Hooks
    HookRegister(trigger Trigger) error
    HookTrigger(event string, data ...interface{}) error

    // Conflicts
    Conflicts() ([]Conflict, error)
    Resolve(strategy string) error
}

// Usage example
func main() {
    avcs := avcs.NewAVCS("~/gt/gastown", "jj")

    // Agent commits work
    agent := avcs.AgentIdentity{
        Rig:     "gastown",
        Type:    "polecat",
        Name:    "nux",
        Session: "sess-456",
    }

    op, err := avcs.Commit(agent, avcs.CommitPayload{
        Message: "Fix authentication bug",
        Beads:   []string{"gt-123"},
        Tags: map[string]string{
            "type":     "bugfix",
            "priority": "1",
        },
    })

    // Hooks auto-trigger
    // - Assign to refinery
    // - Send mail to witness
}
```

title: Discovery and Visualization layer for non-technical builders - anyone else hitting this wall?
body:
I came to vibe coding because I had some ideas of things I wanted to build and went way down the rabbit hold. I recently found Beads and I'm considering integrating Gastown into my flow. I built a workflow wrapper on Beads called Parade so I could have a discovery layer and visualization of what is going on under the hood. 

One of my biggest problem is I don't know what I don't know. When I start with a vague idea, I miss things - technical considerations I've never heard of, domain rules I didn't think to mention, existing patterns in my codebase I could reuse. The AI only knows to address what I bring up. 

I've been experimenting with a discovery layer that runs SME-style agents (technical, business domain, codebase context) to surface questions and considerations I wouldn't have thought to ask. It turns "I want to build an expense tracker" into a spec that includes things like approval workflows, audit logging, and integration points - stuff I would have discovered three days into building when something broke. 

Has anyone else felt this gap? Curious if a structured discovery-to-spec flow upstream of Gastown would be useful to others, or if this is just me compensating for my own lack of technical background.

Here is what I was thinking about:
[fury-road-concept.md](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/24478024/fury-road-concept.md)

title: Iteration Cycle Question
body:
Gas Town is _awesome_. I'm fully coding-agent-pilled. I described it to a coworker as the equivalent of a double-black-diamond ski run, but it's under 3ft of powder (move fast, do crazy hard things you couldn't before, have fun). Gas Town is the powder. or maybe the board. or maybe both?

I'm hitting some issues in work rules and communication patterns with the mayor, and would love insight or recommendations here. I spent most of Friday last week speccing out a new standalone service, riffing with the mayor, going back and forth, feeling the magic. I loved it! The spec was broken down into 6 or 7 epics, and when we finally got to what the mayor deemed a testable state (after epic 4), the codebase was full of stubbed APIs and incomplete work. 

This was frustrating, but I've been doing this long enough (ha, 6 months) to know that it was a me problem and not a "SEE VIBE CODING IS DUMB YOU SHOULD HANDWRITE EVERYTHING" moment. 

So, what should I do differently to get tighter iteration and feedback loops? Is it forcing the polecats to write tests before they write  functional code? focusing on "tracer bullets" first, then testing (shout out Vibe Coding book)? I'm coming from a space where I was having 1-3 instances of Amp iterate on front end code, so I was able to more easily check in on work progress while it was happening.

Open to all ideas here, TYIA!
